Fiscal responsibility: Transparent procurement prevents inflated radar contracts; compensation mechanism for wrongful seizures creates accountability incentive for police
Interagency clarity: Coordination body prevents municipal/national police conflicts and ensures consistent, lawful enforcement nationwide
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: High feasibility with moderate political will. Technical components (zero BAC enforcement, penalty point IT systems, body cameras, tender transparency) are proven technologies used by neighboring EU states and can be implemented within 12-18 months with EU IPA funds available for judiciary and rule of law projects. Judicial review infrastructure exists (Basic Courts handle administrative disputes). Main barriers are: (1) political resistance to removing populist 'tough on young drivers' messaging—requires public education on evidence-based effectiveness; (2) Police Directorate may resist judicial oversight and body cameras—needs Ministry of Interior leadership commitment; (3) drafting requires Constitutional Court informal pre-review (1-2 months) and genuine public consultation (not pro forma)—adds timeline but ensures constitutionality. Cost is comparable to original proposal (radar procurement dominates budget; body cameras ~€200k one-time, offset by corruption reduction). Croatia implemented similar graduated licensing in 2009-2011 during EU accession; Montenegro can adapt their legal framework. Overall, this is achievable if government prioritizes EU compliance and evidence over political optics.
counter_proposal.title_mne: Dokazno zasnovan stepenovan okvir bezbjednosti na putevima sa sudskim garancijama
counter_proposal.summary_mne: Ministarstvo pravde bi predložilo sveobuhvatan sistem stepenovanih vozačkih dozvola usklađen sa najboljim praksama EU, zamjenjujući paušalna starosna vremenska ograničenja dokazno zasnovanim mjerama ublažavanja rizika (nulti BAK, napredna obuka, pragovi kaznenih poena). Sve mjere sprovođenja zakona koje utiču na imovinska prava zahtijevale bi sudsko odobrenje u roku od 24 časa. Transparentan okvir upravljanja uključivao bi obaveznu procjenu uticaja, javne konsultacije, antikorupcijske garancije (kamere na tijelu, ASK nadzor, transparentnost nabavki) i trogodišnju klauzulu o vremenskom važenju sa nezavisnom evaluacijom. Ovaj pristup postiže ciljeve javne bezbjednosti uz poštovanje ustavnih prava, vladavine prava i zahtjeva za pristupanje EU.
key_changes_mne: Zamijeniti zabranu noćne vožnje zahtjevom nultog sadržaja alkohola u krvi (BAK) za vozače mlađe od 21 godine i obaveznim naprednim kursom bezbjednosti od 20 časova u prvoj godini posjedovanja dozvole
Uvesti sistem kaznenih poena sa nižim pragovima za vozače početnike (6 poena naspram 12 za iskusne vozače) koji vodi do suspenzije dozvole, a ne paušalnim vremenskim ograničenjima

Zahtijevati sudsko odobrenje za oduzimanje vozila u roku od 24 časa od policijskog zadržavanja, sa jasno definisanim kvalifikujućim prekršajima (vožnja pod uticajem alkohola sa BAK >0,08%, bezobzirno ugrožavanje koje uzrokuje povrede, napuštanje mjesta nesreće), maksimalnim periodom oduzimanja od 30 dana i automatskom naknadom ako se oduzimanje poništi

Utvrditi strukturu kazni prilagođenu imovinskom stanju za roditeljske prekršaje vezane za električne trotinete: €50-150 za porodice sa niskim primanjima (prihod ispod medijane), €150-300 za srednji prihod, €300-500 za visok prihod, sa opcijom alternativnog društveno korisnog rada

Obavezati sveobuhvatnu procjenu regulatornog uticaja uključujući preliminarno mišljenje Ustavnog suda, reviziju ljudskih prava od strane Zaštitnika i 30-dnevnu javnu konsultaciju prije glasanja u parlamentu

Zahtijevati kamere na tijelu za sve interakcije u saobraćaju koje uključuju potencijalno oduzimanje vozila ili kazne veće od €200, sa čuvanjem snimaka 90 dana i pristupom za okrivljene; ASK da objavljuje kvartalne statistike o oduzimanjima po regionima/službenicima

Podvrgnuti nabavku radara pojačanoj transparentnosti: javni tender sa objavljenim kriterijumima evaluacije, prethodno odobrenje Državne revizorske institucije, objavljivanje ugovora u realnom vremenu na gov.me i učešće posmatrača iz civilnog društva

Uključiti trogodišnju klauzulu o vremenskom važenju za sva ograničenja za mlade vozače sa obaveznom nezavisnom evaluacijom ishoda bezbjednosti na putevima, uticaja na ustavna prava i poređenjem sa pristupima država EU prije produženja

Uspostaviti međuagencijsko koordinaciono tijelo (Ministarstvo pravde, Ministarstvo unutrašnjih poslova, Uprava policije, opštine) za definisanje nadležnosti komunalne policije, razvoj nastavnog programa obuke i rješavanje jurisdikcionih sporova

Eksplicitno uskladiti zakonodavstvo sa Direktivom EU 2006/126/EZ o vozačkim dozvolama i sprovesti formalnu analizu usklađenosti objavljenu uz zakonski predlog — demonstrirati konkretan napredak u mjerilima Poglavlja 23 o pravosuđu i osnovnim pravima
expected_benefits_mne: Ustavna usklađenost: Dokazno zasnovane mjere (nulti BAK, obuka, poeni) ciljaju stvarna rizična ponašanja bez starosne diskriminacije, izdržavajući ocjenu proporcionalnosti pred Ustavnim sudom
Usklađenost sa EKLJP: Sudski nadzor nad oduzimanjem imovine sprečava kršenje člana 1 Protokola 1, smanjujući rizik od skupih presuda EKLJP protiv Crne Gore

Efikasnija bezbjednost na putevima: Nulti BAK za mlade vozače adresira vodeći uzrok smrtonosnih nesreća (alkohol) umjesto doba dana; kazneni poeni stvaraju stepenovan odvraćajući efekat; napredna obuka gradi vještine — dokazano efikasno u državama EU
Jačanje vladavine prava: Jasni pravni kriterijumi, sudske provjere i procesne garancije ograničavaju proizvoljnu policijsku vlast i jačaju povjerenje javnosti u pravosudni sistem

Antikorupcija: Kamere na tijelu, ASK nadzor i transparentnost nabavki smanjuju mogućnosti za podmićivanje, selektivno sprovođenje zakona i manipulaciju ugovorima — opipljiv napredak u mjerilima Poglavlja 23 o borbi protiv korupcije
Socijalna pravičnost: Kazne prilagođene imovinskom stanju sprečavaju nesrazmjerno opterećenje ugroženih porodica uz održavanje odvraćajućeg efekta za prekršioce sa visokim primanjima

Kredibilitet pred EU: Eksplicitno usklađivanje sa direktivama, procjena uticaja i javne konsultacije demonstriraju posvećenost EU standardima, jačajući pregovaračku poziciju u Poglavlju 23 i ukupnom procesu pristupanja
Demokratski legitimitet: Javne konsultacije i klauzula o vremenskom važenju sa evaluacijom obezbjeđuju građanski doprinos i prilagođavanje politika zasnovano na dokazima, a ne nametanje odozgo
Fiskalna odgovornost: Transparentna nabavka sprečava uvećane ugovore za radare; mehanizam naknade za neosnovano oduzimanje stvara podsticaj za odgovornost policije
Međuagencijska jasnoća: Koordinaciono tijelo sprečava konflikte između komunalne i državne policije i obezbjeđuje dosljedno, zakonito sprovođenje zakona na nacionalnom nivou
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility_mne: Visoka izvodljivost uz umjerenu političku volju. Tehničke komponente (sprovođenje nultog BAK-a, IT sistemi za kaznene poene, kamere na tijelu, transparentnost tendera) su dokazane tehnologije koje koriste susjedne države EU i mogu se implementirati u roku od 12-18 mjeseci uz EU IPA sredstva dostupna za projekte pravosuđa i vladavine prava. Infrastruktura za sudsko preispitivanje postoji (Osnovni sudovi rješavaju upravne sporove). Glavne prepreke su: (1) politički otpor uklanjanju populističke poruke 'strogo prema mladim vozačima' — zahtijeva javnu edukaciju o dokazno zasnovanoj efikasnosti; (2) Uprava policije može pružiti otpor sudskom nadzoru i kamerama na tijelu — potrebna je posvećenost rukovodstva Ministarstva unutrašnjih poslova; (3) izrada zahtijeva neformalnu prethodnu reviziju Ustavnog suda (1-2 mjeseca) i istinske javne konsultacije (ne proforma) — produžava rokove ali obezbjeđuje ustavnost. Troškovi su uporedivi sa originalnim predlogom (nabavka radara dominira budžetom; kamere na tijelu ~€200.000 jednokratno, nadoknađeno smanjenjem korupcije). Hrvatska je implementirala sličan sistem stepenovanih dozvola 2009-2011. tokom pristupanja EU; Crna Gora može prilagoditi njihov pravni okvir. Sve u svemu, ovo je ostvarivo ako vlada prioritet da usklađenosti sa EU i dokazima nad političkom optikom.

assessments.summary_mne: Izmjene Zakona o bezbjednosti saobraćaja na putevima teže legitimnim ciljevima javne bezbjednosti, ali pokreću ustavna pitanja u pogledu proporcionalnosti, starosne diskriminacije i pravičnog postupka. Iako je harmonizacija sa EU u oblasti bezbjednosti na putevima pozitivna, zakonodavstvo daje policiji prekomjerna diskreciona ovlašćenja bez adekvatnog sudskog nadzora. Zabrana noćne vožnje za mlade odrasle osobe (18-21) može kršiti ustavne principe jednakosti, a odredbe o oduzimanju vozila nemaju jasne procesne garancije koje zahtijeva član 1 Protokola 1 EKLJP (pravo na imovinu). Roditeljska odgovornost za prekršaje djece na trotinetima je pravno utemeljena. Sve u svemu, zakon zahtijeva doradu kako bi se uspostavila ravnoteža između javne bezbjednosti i zaštite osnovnih prava.
key_concerns_mne: Zabrana vožnje od ponoći za punoljetna lica (18-21) može kršiti ustavnu jednakost (član 8) i slobodu kretanja (član 39) bez jasnog opravdanja proporcionalnosti ili dokazne osnove
Odredba o oduzimanju vozila nema procesne garancije, sudski nadzor i jasne pravne kriterijume — rizikuje kršenje člana 1 Protokola 1 EKLJP i proizvoljno policijsko postupanje
Nema pominjanja javnih konsultacija, procjene regulatornog uticaja ili usklađenosti sa direktivama EU — ne ispunjava standarde dobrog upravljanja iz Poglavlja 23 EU
Roditeljske kazne do €400 mogu biti nesrazmjerne za porodice sa niskim primanjima bez alternativa prilagođenih imovinskom stanju ili planova otplate
Proširena policijska ovlašćenja stvaraju rizike od korupcije bez pratećih mehanizama nadzora (kamere na tijelu, praćenje od strane ASK, transparentna statistika)
Nabavka radara (~100 jedinica) ne pominje garancije transparentnosti protiv koruptivnih tendera
Nije utvrđen okvir za obuku ili odgovornost za proširenu ulogu komunalne policije — rizikuje jurisdikcionu konfuziju i zloupotrebu
Mehanizam sprovođenja starosnih ograničenja za trotinete je nejasan — rizikuje selektivnu i proizvoljnu primjenu
recommendations_mne: Izmijeniti odredbu o oduzimanju vozila tako da zahtijeva: (1) neodložno sudsko odobrenje ili preispitivanje u roku od 24 časa, (2) jasnu definiciju kvalifikujućih prekršaja, (3) maksimalno trajanje oduzimanja, (4) naknadu za neosnovano oduzimanje i (5) javno izvještavanje o svim oduzimanjima

Zamijeniti paušalnu zabranu noćne vožnje dokazno zasnovanim stepenovanim izdavanjem dozvola: nulti BAK za vozače mlađe od 21 godine, obavezna napredna obuka, sistem kaznenih poena sa nižim pragovima za početnike (uskladiti sa hrvatskim/srpskim modelima)

Uvesti smanjenje kazni prilagođeno imovinskom stanju ili alternative u vidu društveno korisnog rada za roditeljske prekršaje vezane za električne trotinete kako bi se osigurala proporcionalnost za ugrožene porodice
Obavezati sveobuhvatnu procjenu regulatornog uticaja uključujući ustavnu reviziju, procjenu osnovnih prava i analizu troškova i koristi prije usvajanja u parlamentu
Zahtijevati kamere na tijelu za sve saobraćajne kontrole koje uključuju potencijalno oduzimanje vozila i ASK nadzor obrazaca sprovođenja zakona radi sprečavanja korupcije i zloupotrebe
Uspostaviti transparentan postupak javne nabavke za radarske sisteme sa prethodnim odobrenjem Državne revizorske institucije i praćenjem od strane civilnog društva (objaviti sve ugovore na gov.me)
Eksplicitno navesti Direktivu EU 2006/126/EZ i sprovesti formalnu analizu usklađenosti kako bi se demonstriralo usklađivanje sa pravnom tekovinom EU — kritično za kredibilitet Poglavlja 23
Sprovesti period javnih konsultacija (minimum 30 dana) sa omladinskim organizacijama, auto-školama, civilnim društvom i Zaštitnikom ljudskih prava i sloboda prije konačnog glasanja u parlamentu
Definisati jasne granice nadležnosti i obavezan nastavni program obuke za sprovođenje saobraćajnih propisa od strane komunalne policije kako bi se spriječili jurisdikcioni konflikti
Uključiti klauzulu o vremenskom važenju (npr. 3 godine) za ograničenja za mlade vozače sa obaveznom evaluacijom efikasnosti i uticaja na prava prije produženja

assessments.summary: The Road Traffic Safety Law amendments represent a significant public health intervention that directly addresses road traffic injuries—a leading cause of death and disability in Montenegro, particularly among young people aged 18-24. The midnight-to-5am driving ban for young drivers targets the highest-risk period for alcohol-related crashes and fatigue-related incidents. Electric scooter regulation fills a critical safety gap that has emerged across EU cities. These measures align with WHO's Safe System approach and will reduce demand on the Clinical Center of Montenegro's emergency departments and trauma services. However, the decision lacks integration with health sector expertise, omits crucial post-crash care improvements, and misses opportunities for data-sharing protocols that would enable evidence-based monitoring of public health outcomes.
assessments.reasoning:
From a public health perspective, road traffic injuries constitute a major preventable cause of mortality and morbidity in Montenegro. Data from the Clinical Center of Montenegro's emergency services show that young drivers (18-24 years) are disproportionately represented in serious traffic crashes, particularly during nighttime hours when alcohol consumption, fatigue, and risk-taking behavior peak. The midnight-to-5am driving restriction for drivers aged 18-21 is evidence-based: international studies demonstrate that graduated driver licensing (GDL) programs with nighttime restrictions reduce fatal crashes among novice drivers by 10-30%.

The 80 kW engine power limit addresses another documented risk factor—young drivers operating high-performance vehicles before developing adequate hazard perception and vehicle control skills. Emergency department physicians at the Clinical Center regularly treat catastrophic injuries from high-speed crashes involving inexperienced drivers in powerful vehicles. This restriction will likely reduce the severity of injuries requiring intensive trauma care, neurosurgery, and long-term rehabilitation—services that are already stretched thin in Montenegro's small healthcare system.

Electric scooter regulation is overdue from an injury prevention standpoint. Since e-scooters proliferated in Podgorica and coastal cities (2023-2025), emergency departments have documented a sharp increase in head injuries, fractures, and soft tissue trauma among users—many of them minors. The minimum age of 16 and parental liability provisions create a regulatory framework similar to successful models in Slovenia and Croatia. However, the decision omits mandatory helmet requirements, which reduce head injury severity by approximately 70% according to WHO guidelines.

The deployment of 100 digital radars and average speed measurement technology supports injury prevention through speed reduction. Excessive speed is a factor in approximately 40% of fatal crashes in Montenegro (per RFZO mortality data). Automated enforcement is more consistent than manual policing and has demonstrated effectiveness in reducing both speed and crash rates across EU member states. The vehicle seizure provision for repeat offenders removes dangerous drivers from the road, preventing injuries before they occur—a core principle of primary prevention in public health.

However, the Ministry of Health identifies several critical gaps. First, there is no evidence that health sector expertise informed the policy design. The Ministry of Health operates the national injury surveillance system and holds detailed epidemiological data on traffic injury patterns, risk factors, and outcomes. This data should have guided the selection of interventions and their calibration (e.g., why midnight rather than 11pm or 1am? What does Montenegro-specific crash data show?). The absence of Health Ministry consultation suggests a siloed policy process that misses opportunities for evidence-based optimization.

Second, the decision focuses exclusively on prevention but ignores the post-crash care continuum. Road traffic injuries place significant strain on emergency medical services (EMS), emergency departments, intensive care units, and rehabilitation services. Montenegro's EMS response times in rural and mountainous areas remain suboptimal (often exceeding WHO's recommended 15-minute benchmark), and the Clinical Center's trauma capacity is limited. A comprehensive traffic safety strategy should include investments in trauma care systems, training for emergency responders, and protocols for rapid transfer to specialized care.

Third, there is no mechanism for health data integration. Police will enforce these new regulations, but they will not systematically share data with RFZO (the health insurance fund) or the Institute of Public Health. This prevents real-time monitoring of the policy's health impact. For example, if emergency department visits for traffic injuries among 18-21 year-olds decline after the midnight curfew, that would validate the intervention. Without data-sharing protocols, such evaluation is impossible.

Fourth, the decision does not address alcohol-impaired driving comprehensively. While the nighttime curfew for young drivers will reduce some alcohol-related crashes, it does not tackle the broader issue of drink-driving across all age groups. Montenegro's blood alcohol concentration (BAC) limit of 0.03% is relatively strict, but enforcement is inconsistent, and random breath testing is underutilized. The Ministry of Health supports zero-tolerance BAC limits for all drivers and mandatory alcohol screening in emergency departments to identify high-risk individuals for brief intervention.

Fifth, the fines and penalties are purely punitive with no integration of health education or rehabilitation. For example, young drivers who violate the nighttime curfew could be required to complete a traffic safety education program that includes modules on injury biomechanics, alcohol effects on reaction time, and testimonials from crash survivors. Such programs have demonstrated effectiveness in changing behavior among young drivers in Finland and the Netherlands.

Finally, the decision does not address vulnerable road users beyond e-scooter riders—pedestrians and cyclists. Montenegro's urban design heavily favors motor vehicles, and pedestrian fatalities remain high, particularly among the elderly. A truly comprehensive traffic safety law would include measures such as lower urban speed limits (30 km/h in residential areas), protected cycling infrastructure, and pedestrian priority zones near schools and hospitals.

Despite these limitations, the decision represents meaningful progress. It applies evidence-based interventions (graduated licensing, speed enforcement, powered two-wheeler regulation) that will save lives and reduce the burden on Montenegro's healthcare system. The Ministry of Health therefore assigns a positive verdict with a score of 7/10, recognizing the public health value while noting significant opportunities for improvement through health sector integration and a more comprehensive Safe System approach.
key_concerns: No evidence of Ministry of Health consultation or use of health sector injury surveillance data in policy design, suggesting a siloed approach that may miss Montenegro-specific risk factors
Exclusive focus on prevention with no investment in post-crash emergency medical services, trauma care capacity, or rehabilitation—critical gaps given Montenegro's limited EMS coverage in rural areas
Absence of data-sharing protocols between police and health sector (RFZO, Institute of Public Health) prevents monitoring of public health outcomes and evidence-based policy adjustment
Electric scooter regulation omits mandatory helmet requirements, which reduce head injury severity by ~70% and should be a baseline safety measure
No integration of health education or behavior change programs into the penalty framework—missed opportunity for secondary prevention
Fails to address broader alcohol-impaired driving through measures like random breath testing, zero-BAC limits, or emergency department screening for high-risk drivers
Neglects vulnerable road users (pedestrians, cyclists, elderly) who account for significant traffic injury burden but receive no specific protections in this amendment
Deployment of 100 digital radars lacks transparency on placement criteria—health data should inform prioritization of high-injury corridors rather than revenue optimization
recommendations: Establish a formal inter-ministerial working group (Interior, Health, Transport) to integrate health sector injury data into ongoing traffic safety policy development and enforcement priority-setting
Mandate data-sharing protocols requiring police to provide monthly traffic injury data to the Institute of Public Health and RFZO for real-time epidemiological monitoring and policy evaluation
Amend electric scooter regulations to require helmets for all riders and integrate with EU safety standards (EN 1078), with public education campaigns led by the Ministry of Health
Allocate portion of fine revenue to strengthen emergency medical services in high-crash rural areas, including advanced EMS training and rapid transfer protocols to Clinical Center trauma services
Introduce mandatory traffic safety education programs for violators, developed by the Ministry of Health using injury data and behavioral science, as alternative or supplement to monetary fines
Expand alcohol enforcement through random breath testing, zero-BAC limits for all drivers, and emergency department screening protocols to identify and intervene with high-risk individuals

Commission joint study by Ministry of Health and Institute of Public Health to evaluate nighttime curfew impact on 18-21 year-old injury rates after 12 months, with results informing policy refinement
Use health sector injury mapping data to guide digital radar placement prioritizing high-injury corridors near hospitals, schools, and residential areas rather than revenue-generating highways

counter_proposal.title: Integrated Road Safety & Trauma Care Strategy 2026-2030
counter_proposal.summary: The Ministry of Health proposes embedding these traffic law amendments within a comprehensive National Road Safety and Trauma Care Strategy that integrates prevention, enforcement, and post-crash care. This approach recognizes that reducing road traffic deaths and disability requires simultaneous action across the Safe System pillars: safer road users (current focus), safer vehicles, safer speeds, safer roads, and post-crash care (currently neglected). The strategy would establish a permanent inter-ministerial coordination body co-chaired by Interior and Health, mandate systematic health data integration into enforcement planning, redirect a portion of fine revenue to trauma system strengthening, and introduce health-led behavior change interventions alongside punitive measures. This transforms a good enforcement-focused law into a holistic public health intervention aligned with WHO's Global Plan for the Decade of Action for Road Safety 2021-2030 and EU best practices in Vision Zero approaches.
key_changes: Create permanent National Road Safety Council co-chaired by Ministers of Interior and Health, with mandatory quarterly meetings and data-driven priority-setting using health sector injury surveillance

Establish real-time data exchange protocol: police provide crash and citation data to Institute of Public Health within 48 hours, enabling epidemiological monitoring and evidence-based policy adjustment

Amend electric scooter provisions to mandate helmets (EN 1078 standard), prohibit pavement riding, and require reflective elements and lights—aligned with best-practice models from the Netherlands and Denmark

Dedicate 30% of traffic fine revenue to Emergency Medical Services modernization: advanced trauma training, ambulance fleet renewal, telemedicine links to Clinical Center, and response time monitoring in rural areas

Replace purely punitive fines for first-time young driver violations with mandatory attendance at health-led 'Road Trauma Reality' workshops featuring injury biomechanics education and survivor testimonials, proven effective in Nordic countries

Introduce comprehensive alcohol strategy: zero-BAC for all drivers (not just young/novice), random breath testing authority, and mandatory screening protocols in Clinical Center emergency department to identify high-risk drinkers for brief intervention

Extend graduated licensing beyond age restrictions: include hazard perception testing (currently absent in Montenegro driver licensing), minimum supervised driving hours, and restrictions on peer passengers (high crash risk factor)

Add vulnerable road user protections: 30 km/h urban speed limits near schools/hospitals, protected cycling infrastructure investment, pedestrian priority zones—informed by health sector injury mapping of high-risk locations
Require health impact assessment for digital radar placement using Institute of Public Health crash injury data, prioritizing high-injury corridors rather than revenue generation

Mandate annual public reporting of road safety outcomes using health metrics (lives saved, serious injuries prevented, disability-adjusted life years, healthcare cost savings) alongside enforcement statistics
expected_benefits: Reduction of 15-25% in road traffic deaths within 3 years (evidence from comparable GDL + Safe System programs in Slovenia, Estonia), preventing 8-15 deaths annually in Montenegro's context
Decrease in emergency department traffic injury presentations by 20-30%, reducing strain on Clinical Center trauma services and freeing capacity for other urgent care
Improved rural EMS response times through dedicated investment, potentially saving 3-5 lives per year in time-critical golden hour trauma cases
Enhanced policy agility through real-time health data monitoring—ability to adjust interventions within months rather than years if injury patterns change
Behavioral change among young drivers through education programs, creating longer-lasting safety culture than fines alone (Nordic evaluation data shows 35% reduction in repeat violations)
Reduced alcohol-impaired driving across all age groups through comprehensive strategy, addressing 30-40% of fatal crashes currently attributed to alcohol in Montenegro
Better protection for elderly pedestrians and cyclists (vulnerable populations with high injury severity), reducing disability and long-term care burden on health and social systems
Alignment with EU Chapter 28 (Consumer and Health Protection) requirements and WHO road safety frameworks, strengthening Montenegro's EU accession profile
Cost savings for RFZO: estimated €2-4 million annually in avoided trauma care, rehabilitation, and long-term disability costs—savings that exceed implementation costs within 2-3 years
Transparent, evidence-based governance that builds public trust through visible health outcome improvements and accountability for road safety investments
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: Highly feasible with moderate political will and coordination effort. The core amendments are already approved—the Ministry of Health's proposal simply embeds them in a strategic framework and redirects existing resources (fine revenue) rather than requiring large new budgets. Inter-ministerial coordination mechanisms exist (Government sessions, working groups) and need formalization rather than creation from scratch. Data-sharing protocols can be established through ministerial agreement and IT integration between police systems and Institute of Public Health databases (estimated 6-9 months, modest IT investment). EMS improvements are scalable and can be phased over 2-3 years as fine revenue accumulates. Health education programs can be piloted in 2-3 municipalities before national rollout. Helmet mandates for e-scooters require regulatory amendment but face minimal implementation barriers (enforcement piggybacks on existing police authority). The primary challenge is overcoming institutional silos—Interior Ministry viewing traffic safety as an enforcement domain rather than a public health issue. However, shared outcome metrics (lives saved) and EU accession pressure for integrated governance create favorable conditions. Comparable integrated road safety strategies have been successfully implemented in Croatia (2011), Slovenia (2013), and Estonia (2015) with similar institutional starting points. Estimated implementation timeline: 6 months for strategy development and inter-ministerial agreements, 12-18 months for full operationalization of data systems and training programs, 3 years to achieve measurable health outcome improvements. Political feasibility is moderate-to-high if framed as enhancing rather than replacing the existing law, and if public communication emphasizes lives saved and healthcare cost reductions.

Osnovne izmjene su već usvojene — predlog Ministarstva zdravlja ih jednostavno ugrađuje u strateški okvir i preusmjerava postojeće resurse (prihode od kazni) umjesto da zahtijeva velika nova budžetska sredstva. Primarni izazov je prevazilaženje institucionalnih silosa — Ministarstvo unutrašnjih poslova koje posmatra bezbjednost saobraćaja kao domen sprovođenja zakona a ne kao javnozdravstveno pitanje. debate.consensus_summary: All ministries acknowledge that the Road Traffic Safety Law amendments address a legitimate and urgent public safety need. # Parliamentary Debate: Road Traffic Safety Law Amendments

## Opening Remarks: Framing the Decision

The government's approval of Road Traffic Safety Law amendments on February 12, 2026 introduces three major policy changes: (1) midnight-to-5am driving ban for 18-21 year-olds, (2) first-time regulation of electric scooters with age 16 minimum and parental fines, and (3) expanded police powers including vehicle seizure and deployment of approximately 100 digital radars. The stated objective is reducing road fatalities among young people, Montenegro's most vulnerable traffic demographic.

This debate examines whether the decision strikes an appropriate balance between public safety, fiscal responsibility, constitutional rights, and economic impact.

---

## I. CONSENSUS AREAS: Shared Ground Across Ministries

### A. Legitimacy of Public Safety Objective

**The Ministry of Health** frames the urgency clearly: "Road traffic injuries are a leading cause of death and disability in Montenegro, particularly among young people aged 18-24. The midnight-to-5am driving ban targets the highest-risk period for alcohol-related crashes and fatigue-related incidents."

**The Ministry of Education** concurs from a student welfare perspective: "These measures directly protect our student population, particularly secondary school and university students aged 16-21 who represent a vulnerable demographic in traffic incidents."

**The Ministry of Interior** adds enforcement credibility: "The young driver restrictions align with EU best practices, while electric scooter regulation addresses a genuine regulatory gap."

**Point of consensus:** No ministry disputes that young drivers are statistically overrepresented in traffic fatalities, or that electric scooters have created an unregulated safety hazard. The policy problem is real.

### B. EU Alignment and Regional Competitiveness

**The Ministry of EU Integration** endorses the strategic direction: "The Road Traffic Safety Law amendments represent a positive step toward EU acquis alignment, particularly with Directive 2015/413 on cross-border enforcement and the broader EU road safety framework."

**The Ministry of Justice** agrees on international obligations: "EU harmonization in road safety is positive... these measures pursue legitimate public safety objectives."

**Point of consensus:** The decision positions Montenegro favorably in Chapter 14 (Transport Policy) negotiations and demonstrates capacity to transpose EU safety standards, a credibility signal to Brussels.

### C. Need for Electric Scooter Regulation

**The Ministry of Interior** identifies the gap: "Electric scooter regulation addresses a genuine regulatory gap."

**The Ministry of Health** quantifies the risk: "Electric scooter regulation fills a critical safety gap that has emerged across EU cities."

**Point of consensus:** All ministries acknowledge that Montenegro's silence on electric scooters created legal uncertainty and safety hazards. Regulation is overdue.

---

## II. POINTS OF CONTENTION: Where Ministries Diverge

### A. Constitutional Proportionality of the Midnight Driving Ban

#### **The Case for Restrictions (Health, Education, Interior)**

**The Ministry of Health** presents the epidemiological argument: "The midnight-to-5am driving ban for young drivers targets the highest-risk period for alcohol-related crashes and fatigue-related incidents. These measures align with WHO's Safe System approach and will reduce demand on the Clinical Center of Montenegro's emergency departments and trauma services."

**The Ministry of Education** emphasizes duty of care: "The midnight-to-5am driving ban for young drivers and electric scooter age restrictions align with our duty of care for student welfare."

**The Ministry of Interior** cites evidence-based policymaking: "The young driver restrictions align with EU best practices."

#### **The Case Against Blanket Bans (Justice, Economy)**

**The Ministry of Justice** raises constitutional red flags: "Midnight driving ban for legal adults (18-21) may violate constitutional equality (Article 8) and freedom of movement (Article 39) without clear proportionality justification or evidence base... Replace blanket midnight driving ban with evidence-based graduated licensing: zero BAC for drivers under 21, mandatory advanced training, penalty point system with lower thresholds for novices."

**The Ministry of Economy** identifies labor market impacts: "Youth employment mobility reduced in tourism/hospitality sectors due to midnight-to-5am driving ban, particularly in coastal areas with limited public transport... Potential negative effect on informal economy workers (20-30% of labor force) who rely on night mobility for income."

**The Ministry of EU Integration** notes human rights concerns: "Midnight-5am driving ban may disproportionately affect rural youth's access to employment/education without adequate public transport alternatives, raising proportionality concerns under EU fundamental rights framework."

**Parliamentary Question:** Is a blanket age-based driving ban on legal adults constitutionally defensible, or should Montenegro adopt a graduated licensing system (as Justice recommends) that imposes stricter conditions (zero BAC, lower penalty thresholds, mandatory training) without categorical time-based restrictions?

**Strongest argument for restrictions:** Health's injury data showing midnight-5am as peak crash risk period, combined with Education's duty of care for students.

**Strongest argument against:** Justice's proportionality analysis and Economy's documentation of labor market impacts on night-shift workers, particularly in tourism-dependent coastal municipalities.

**Potential compromise:** Justice's graduated licensing model preserves safety gains (zero BAC, heightened scrutiny) while avoiding categorical age-based freedom of movement restrictions that may fail constitutional review.

---

### B. Fiscal Preparedness and Budget Allocation

#### **The Fiscal Skeptics (Finance, Economy)**

**The Ministry of Finance** itemizes the gaps: "No budget allocation specified for approximately 100 digital radars (estimated €1.5-5 million capital cost), absence of cost-benefit analysis comparing safety benefits to fiscal expenditure, missing revenue projections from fines despite introduction of €300-600 penalties, no assessment of recurring costs (maintenance, data processing, personnel training)."

**The Ministry of Economy** questions return on investment: "Enforcement costs (100 digital radars, expanded police authority) represent €2-5 million fiscal commitment with no ROI analysis or efficiency benchmarks."

#### **The Implementation Realists (Interior, EU Integration)**

**The Ministry of Interior** acknowledges capacity concerns: "No evidence of police capacity analysis for deploying and maintaining 100 digital radars and average speed systems — risks unfunded mandate and implementation failure... Absent budget allocation and procurement timeline for technology deployment — high risk of delays, cost overruns, or corrupt procurement practices."

**The Ministry of EU Integration** offers a solution: "No mention of IPA funding mechanisms for digital radar procurement, risking non-compliance with EU public procurement rules and missing technical assistance opportunities... Designate IPA III funding for digital radar procurement and tie it to public procurement procedures compliant with Chapter 5 benchmarks; request EC technical assistance for implementation."

**Parliamentary Question:** Should the government halt implementation until Finance produces a full cost-benefit analysis and secures budget allocation, or proceed immediately while seeking IPA III co-financing as EU Integration recommends?

**Strongest fiscal argument:** Finance's documentation that the decision lacks basic budgetary discipline—no capital cost estimates, no revenue projections, no recurring cost analysis. This violates fiscal responsibility principles.

**Strongest implementation argument:** EU Integration's identification of IPA III funding as a viable path forward, transforming a fiscal liability into an EU integration opportunity with technical assistance.

**Recommendation:** Parliament should condition final approval on two deliverables within 60 days: (1) Finance-certified cost-benefit analysis with 3-year fiscal impact projection, and (2) EU Integration-led IPA III funding application with procurement timeline.

---

### C. Enforcement vs. Prevention Balance

#### **The Prevention Coalition (Health, Education, Justice)**

**The Ministry of Health** advocates for behavioral intervention: "Exclusive focus on prevention with no investment in post-crash emergency medical services, trauma care capacity, or rehabilitation... Absence of data-sharing protocols between police and health sector prevents monitoring of public health outcomes... Introduce mandatory traffic safety education programs for violators, developed by the Ministry of Health using injury data and behavioral science, as alternative or supplement to monetary fines."

**The Ministry of Education** identifies the missing educational component: "No integration of traffic safety education into mandatory school curriculum despite clear policy need... Purely punitive approach without educational component for young offenders (e.g., mandatory safety courses)... Mandate traffic safety module integration into final year of secondary education (age 17-18) covering new regulations, defensive driving, and consequences."

**The Ministry of Justice** proposes graduated alternatives: "Replace blanket midnight driving ban with evidence-based graduated licensing: zero BAC for drivers under 21, mandatory advanced training, penalty point system with lower thresholds for novices."

#### **The Enforcement Priority (Interior)**

**The Ministry of Interior** focuses on technology and police powers: "The decision raises significant concerns about police administrative capacity, digital infrastructure readiness, data protection compliance, and the lack of a comprehensive road safety strategy integrating prevention, education, and inter-agency coordination... However, enforcement-only approach treats symptoms, not root causes."

**Parliamentary Question:** Has the government over-indexed on enforcement technology (radars, fines, seizures) while neglecting prevention infrastructure (driver education reform, behavioral interventions, health sector integration)?

**Strongest prevention argument:** Health and Education's evidence-based case that mandatory safety courses for violators and curriculum integration would reduce recidivism more effectively than fines alone, particularly for low-income youth.

**Strongest enforcement argument:** Interior's acknowledgment that even with enforcement focus, the current decision lacks a "comprehensive road safety strategy integrating prevention, education, infrastructure, and inter-agency coordination"—conceding the prevention coalition's critique.

**Recommendation:** Parliament should mandate an inter-ministerial working group (Interior, Health, Education, Transport) to develop a national road safety strategy (2026-2030) integrating enforcement, prevention, education, and infrastructure improvements, with measurable targets aligned to EU Vision Zero principles.

---

### D. Data Protection, Oversight, and Corruption Risks

#### **The Accountability Skeptics (Justice, Interior, EU Integration)**

**The Ministry of Justice** flags corruption vulnerabilities: "Vehicle seizure provision lacks procedural safeguards, judicial oversight, and clear legal criteria—risks ECHR Article 1 Protocol 1 violations and arbitrary police discretion... Expanded police powers create corruption risks without accompanying oversight mechanisms (body cameras, ASK monitoring, transparent statistics)... Radar procurement (~100 units) lacks mentioned transparency safeguards against corrupt tendering."

**The Ministry of Interior** identifies GDPR gaps: "Missing data protection impact assessment for automated enforcement systems — exposes Montenegro to GDPR non-compliance and EU criticism during Chapter 23 negotiations... Municipal police capacity varies wildly across municipalities — delegation of authority without standardized training and oversight creates enforcement gaps and corruption risks."

**The Ministry of EU Integration** emphasizes institutional capacity: "Lack of institutional capacity-building measures for police (training on proportionality, due process, GDPR compliance) to accompany expanded enforcement powers... Insufficient data protection safeguards detailed for radar systems and vehicle databases—GDPR compliance unclear."

**Parliamentary Question:** Can Montenegro deploy 100 digital radars and expanded vehicle seizure powers without GDPR compliance, transparent procurement, judicial oversight, and anti-corruption safeguards?

**Strongest accountability argument:** Justice's comprehensive critique documenting that vehicle seizure lacks judicial review, radar procurement lacks transparency, and municipal police expansion lacks standardized training—a trifecta of corruption risks.

**Strongest counter-argument:** None. Even Interior (the implementing ministry) concedes these gaps exist and recommends remediation.

**Recommendation:** Parliament should reject the decision unless amended to include: (1) mandatory Data Protection Impact Assessment before radar deployment, (2) judicial authorization or 24-hour review for all vehicle seizures, (3) transparent public procurement with civil society monitoring, (4) mandatory body cameras for seizure-eligible stops, and (5) ASK oversight of enforcement statistics.

---

### E. Economic Impact on Youth Employment and Tourism

#### **The Economic Concern (Economy, Finance)**

**The Ministry of Economy** quantifies labor market effects: "Youth employment mobility reduced in tourism/hospitality sectors due to midnight-to-5am driving ban, particularly in coastal areas with limited public transport... No consultation mentioned with Chamber of Commerce, Hospitality Association, or tourism stakeholders before approval... Potential negative effect on informal economy workers (20-30% of labor force) who rely on night mobility for income."

**The Ministry of Finance** adds fiscal dimension: "Potential negative impact on youth employment in night-shift sectors (tourism, hospitality)... No assessment of recurring costs, maintenance expenses, and potential impact on consumer spending by young adults."

#### **The Public Health Rebuttal (Health, Education)**

**The Ministry of Health** prioritizes lives over convenience: "The midnight-to-5am driving ban for young drivers targets the highest-risk period for alcohol-related crashes and fatigue-related incidents. These measures align with WHO's Safe System approach and will reduce demand on the Clinical Center of Montenegro's emergency departments and trauma services."

**The Ministry of Education** emphasizes student welfare: "These measures directly protect our student population."

**Parliamentary Question:** Should economic considerations (youth employment in tourism) override public health evidence on peak crash risk hours?

**Strongest economic argument:** Economy's documentation that 20-30% of the labor force works in the informal economy, many in night-shift roles, combined with Finance's concern about youth consumer spending impacts.

**Strongest public health argument:** Health's WHO Safe System framework and emergency department burden reduction—lives saved vs. labor market convenience.

**Potential compromise:** Economy's recommendation to "create exemptions for young workers with documented night-shift employment in registered businesses (hospitality, healthcare, transport) to preserve labor market flexibility" could balance safety and economic needs.

---

### F. Electric Scooter Regulation: Incomplete Framework

#### **The Safety Gap (Health, Interior, Justice)**

**The Ministry of Health** identifies the helmet omission: "Electric scooter regulation omits mandatory helmet requirements, which reduce head injury severity by ~70% and should be a baseline safety measure... Amend electric scooter regulations to require helmets for all riders and integrate with EU safety standards (EN 1078)."

**The Ministry of Interior** lists missing elements: "Electric scooter regulation incomplete — lacks helmet requirements, speed limits, lane usage rules, rental company obligations, and insurance framework... Issue comprehensive electric scooter regulation within 90 days: helmet requirements, speed limits (25 km/h standard), dedicated lane rules, rental company licensing, insurance obligations, and import/sale standards."

**The Ministry of Justice** notes enforcement ambiguity: "Enforcement mechanism for scooter age restrictions unclear—risks selective and arbitrary application."

#### **The Business Development Concern (Economy)**

**The Ministry of Economy** worries about sector stagnation: "Electric scooter regulations introduced without accompanying infrastructure investment (bike lanes, parking zones) or business development incentives... Regional competitiveness risk: Croatia and Albania investing in micro-mobility infrastructure to attract eco-conscious tourists, while Montenegro only regulates without enabling."

**Parliamentary Question:** Should Parliament accept incomplete electric scooter regulation (no helmets, no speed limits, no rental company rules) or demand comprehensive framework before approval?

**Consensus view:** All ministries agree the current electric scooter provisions are incomplete. Health, Interior, and Justice want safety additions; Economy wants infrastructure investment and business development incentives.

**Recommendation:** Parliament should table the electric scooter provisions and instruct Interior to produce comprehensive regulation within 90 days incorporating: helmets (EN 1078 standard), 25 km/h speed limit, lane usage rules, rental company licensing, insurance framework, and municipal infrastructure investment plan (bike lanes, parking zones) co-financed via IPA III.

---

## III. CROSS-CUTTING CONCERNS: Systemic Issues

### A. Lack of Inter-Ministerial Coordination

**The Ministry of Health** laments exclusion: "No evidence of Ministry of Health consultation or use of health sector injury surveillance data in policy design, suggesting a siloed approach that may miss Montenegro-specific risk factors."

**The Ministry of Education** echoes isolation: "No integration of traffic safety education into mandatory school curriculum despite clear policy need, absence of coordination mechanism between Ministry of Education, schools, and traffic police."

**The Ministry of EU Integration** identifies governance failure: "Missing opportunity for regional coordination with Serbia, North Macedonia, Albania under Transport Community Treaty, weakening Western Balkans cooperation narrative... Create an inter-ministerial coordination mechanism (Interior, Transport, EU Integration, Justice) to ensure all implementing regulations undergo EU compatibility screening."

**The Ministry of Economy** notes stakeholder exclusion: "No consultation mentioned with Chamber of Commerce, Hospitality Association, or tourism stakeholders before approval."

**The Ministry of Justice** faults process: "No mention of public consultation, regulatory impact assessment, or EU directive alignment—fails EU Chapter 23 good governance standards."

**Cross-cutting critique:** Five ministries independently identify lack of consultation, coordination, and regulatory impact assessment. This suggests the decision was rushed without proper inter-ministerial vetting or stakeholder engagement—a governance failure.

**Recommendation:** Parliament should mandate 30-day public consultation period and inter-ministerial regulatory impact assessment before final vote, as Justice recommends.

---

### B. Missing Evidence Base and Monitoring Framework

**The Ministry of Finance** notes data gaps: "No baseline violation data to project enforcement rates and actual revenue."

**The Ministry of Interior** identifies systemic failure: "No systematic crash data analysis framework — fragmented reporting between police, courts, and hospitals prevents evidence-based policymaking."

**The Ministry of Health** demands monitoring: "Absence of data-sharing protocols between police and health sector (RFZO, Institute of Public Health) prevents monitoring of public health outcomes and evidence-based policy adjustment... Mandate data-sharing protocols requiring police to provide monthly traffic injury data to the Institute of Public Health and RFZO for real-time epidemiological monitoring and policy evaluation."

**The Ministry of Education** wants transparency: "Create public dashboard showing youth traffic statistics by municipality, accessible to schools for local awareness tailoring."

**The Ministry of EU Integration** sets measurable targets: "Establish measurable road safety targets (e.g., 20% fatality reduction by 2028) aligned with EU Vision Zero and report progress in annual EU integration reports."

**Cross-cutting critique:** The decision lacks baseline data, monitoring mechanisms, and measurable targets—making it impossible to evaluate effectiveness or adjust policy based on evidence.

**Recommendation:** Parliament should require: (1) Interior to establish centralized road crash database integrating police, hospital, and court data within 6 months, (2) Health to publish quarterly injury statistics by age group and time of day, (3) EU Integration to define measurable road safety targets aligned with Vision Zero, and (4) annual parliamentary review of outcomes.

---

## IV. OVERALL VERDICT: Conditional Positive with Mandatory Amendments

### Synthesis of Ministry Positions

**Positive (7/10):** Health, Education, Interior, EU Integration  
**Neutral (5-6/10):** Finance, Economy, Justice

**Weighted assessment:** The decision enjoys majority support among ministries for its core public safety objectives and EU alignment. However, serious implementation gaps (fiscal, constitutional, data protection, oversight) prevent unconditional endorsement.

### The Strongest Arguments

**In favor of the decision:**
1. **Health's injury data:** Midnight-5am is the highest-risk period for young driver crashes; evidence-based targeting of peak danger hours will save lives and reduce emergency department burden.
2. **EU Integration's acquis alignment:** The decision advances Chapter 14 (Transport Policy) and demonstrates Montenegro's capacity to transpose EU road safety standards.
3. **Education's student welfare imperative:** Young drivers aged 18-21 are disproportionately students; the state has a duty of care to protect this vulnerable population.

**Against unconditional approval:**
1. **Justice's constitutional proportionality concerns:** Blanket midnight driving ban on legal adults may violate equality and freedom of movement guarantees; graduated licensing (zero BAC, heightened penalties, mandatory training) achieves safety goals without categorical age-based restrictions.
2. **Finance's fiscal irresponsibility:** €1.5-5M capital cost for 100 radars with no budget allocation, cost-benefit analysis, or revenue projection violates basic fiscal discipline.
3. **Interior's own capacity warnings:** The implementing ministry itself warns of "unfunded mandate and implementation failure" due to missing police capacity analysis, GDPR compliance, and procurement timeline.
4. **Economy's labor market impacts:** 20-30% of workforce in informal economy, many young workers in night-shift tourism/hospitality roles, will face mobility barriers without public transport alternatives.

### Parliamentary Verdict

The Montenegrin Parliament should **conditionally support** the Road Traffic Safety Law amendments, subject to mandatory revisions addressing constitutional, fiscal, and implementation gaps. The core policy intent—reducing young driver fatalities and regulating electric scooters—is sound and EU-aligned. However, the execution is premature and legally vulnerable.

**Required amendments before final approval:**

1. **Constitutional safeguards (Justice):** Replace blanket midnight driving ban with graduated licensing system (zero BAC for under-21, mandatory advanced training, lower penalty thresholds) to preserve safety gains while respecting freedom of movement.

2. **Fiscal accountability (Finance):** Produce comprehensive cost-benefit analysis, 3-year budget impact projection, and identify funding source (IPA III co-financing or domestic budget reallocation) within 60 days.

3. **Data protection compliance (Interior, EU Integration):** Commission Data Protection Impact Assessment before radar deployment; ensure GDPR compliance and Agency for Personal Data Protection approval.

4. **Judicial oversight (Justice):** Amend vehicle seizure provision to require judicial authorization or 24-hour review, clear legal criteria, maximum seizure duration, and compensation for wrongful seizure.

5. **Transparent procurement (Justice, Economy):** Publish radar procurement plan with technical specifications, budget, timeline, and evaluation criteria; conduct open tender with civil society monitoring.

6. **Electric scooter completion (Health, Interior):** Issue comprehensive regulation within 90 days including helmets (EN 1078), 25 km/h speed limit, lane rules, rental company licensing, and insurance framework.

7. **Inter-ministerial coordination (all ministries):** Establish working group (Interior, Health, Education, Transport, EU Integration) to develop national road safety strategy (2026-2030) integrating enforcement, prevention, education, and infrastructure.

8. **Evidence-based monitoring (Health, Interior, EU Integration):** Create centralized crash database integrating police, hospital, and court data; mandate data-sharing protocols; set measurable Vision Zero targets; publish quarterly statistics.

9. **Public consultation (Justice, Economy):** Conduct 30-day consultation with youth organizations, Chamber of Commerce, Hospitality Association, Ombudsman, and civil society before parliamentary vote.

10. **Economic mitigation (Economy):** Create exemptions for documented night-shift workers in registered businesses; develop public transport improvement strategy for coastal municipalities.

### Final Recommendation to Parliament

**Vote to approve the Road Traffic Safety Law amendments in principle, but table final adoption pending 90-day revision period to incorporate the ten mandatory amendments above.**

This approach:
- **Affirms the government's public safety leadership** and EU integration commitment
- **Protects constitutional rights** by requiring graduated licensing instead of blanket age-based bans
- **Ensures fiscal responsibility** by mandating cost-benefit analysis and IPA III funding strategy
- **Prevents corruption** through transparent procurement, judicial oversight, and GDPR compliance
- **Balances safety and economy** via worker exemptions and public transport investment
- **Enables evidence-based policy** through crash data integration and measurable targets
- **Strengthens governance** by requiring inter-ministerial coordination and public consultation

The Montenegrin people deserve road safety reforms that are **constitutionally sound, fiscally responsible, and effectively implemented**—not rushed legislation with good intentions but poor execution. Parliament's duty is to refine this decision into a model of evidence-based, rights-respecting, EU-aligned policymaking that other Western Balkan countries will emulate.

---

## V. CONCLUSION: A Test of Parliamentary Rigor

This debate reveals a fundamental tension in Montenegrin governance: the executive's ambition to demonstrate EU alignment and public safety leadership versus the legislature's constitutional duty to ensure fiscal discipline, fundamental rights protection, and implementation feasibility.

The Road Traffic Safety Law amendments will save lives **if implemented correctly**. They will waste taxpayer money, violate constitutional rights, and fail enforcement **if rushed through without amendments**.

Parliament's choice is clear: demand the rigor that the Montenegrin people and EU accession process require, or rubber-stamp a well-intentioned but legally and fiscally vulnerable decision.

The opposition's role is to hold the government accountable for the ten mandatory amendments. The ruling coalition's role is to demonstrate that it values evidence-based governance over political expediency.

Montenegro's credibility in Chapter 23 (Judiciary and Fundamental Rights) and Chapter 14 (Transport Policy) depends on getting this right.

critic_report.overall_analysis:
This decision exemplifies well-intentioned but poorly executed policymaking—strong on political signaling, weak on evidence and implementation planning.

**The Good:** The government correctly identifies young drivers and electric scooters as road safety priorities. EU data supports graduated licensing, and Montenegro's 7-8 per 100k fatality rate demands action. Digital radar deployment modernizes enforcement. The parental liability mechanism for scooter violations is legally sound and addresses a real gap.

**The Bad:** This is policy theater masquerading as reform. The midnight driving ban sounds tough but lacks enforcement mechanism—will police set up checkpoints on every rural road? Young drivers will simply borrow parents' cars or register vehicles in family names. The €1.5-5M radar procurement has no budget source, no timeline, no transparency safeguards, and—critically—no cost-benefit analysis. Will 100 radars save more lives than investing €5M in EMS helicopters for rural trauma transport? We don't know, because the government didn't ask.

**The Ugly:** Constitutional equality concerns are real. Legal adults (18-21) can vote, marry, own property, and serve in the military—but can't drive to a night shift? The Venice Commission would likely flag this as disproportionate. Vehicle seizure without immediate judicial review violates ECHR property rights. The law creates corruption opportunities: discretionary police powers, major procurement contract, expanded municipal police authority—all without mentioned oversight.

**What Ministries Missed:** None calculated the human capital cost: every young life saved is worth ~€3-5M in lifetime productivity (EU standard). None questioned why Montenegro copies punitive EU measures (curfews, power limits) but ignores proven prevention: Sweden's Vision Zero invests in road design and trauma care; Netherlands focuses on infrastructure separation. None asked: if this works, why do France and Austria—with similar restrictions—still have higher youth fatality rates than Sweden and UK, which use education-based approaches?

**The Real Story:** This decision protects the government from criticism ("we did something about road deaths") without solving the problem. Montenegro's road safety crisis stems from: poor road infrastructure (narrow, poorly lit mountain roads), weak DUI enforcement (breathalyzers rarely used), inadequate EMS coverage (>30min response times in rural areas), and cultural acceptance of reckless driving. A midnight curfew for 18-21 year-olds addresses none of this.

**Cui Bono?** Radar vendors (€1.5-5M contract with no competitive tender safeguards). Police unions (expanded powers, bigger budgets). Politicians ("tough on road safety" talking points). Not benefiting: young workers losing income opportunities, rural families with limited transport options, taxpayers funding unfunded mandates, or—most importantly—the actual victims of Montenegro's road safety crisis, who will keep dying because this law tackles symptoms, not causes.

**The EU Angle:** Brussels will applaud the optics ("harmonization!") but the European Commission's own impact assessment guidelines require cost-benefit analysis, stakeholder consultation, proportionality review, and alternatives assessment. This decision has none. If Montenegro submitted this as EU legislation, it would fail scrutiny. Why accept lower standards domestically?

**Verdict:** A 6/10 decision—better than nothing, worse than evidence-based policy. It will modestly reduce some youth crashes (perhaps 5-10% among the restricted age group) while creating enforcement chaos, constitutional challenges, and missed opportunities for systemic reform. Ministries deserve 8/10 for assessment quality—they identified real concerns—but none had the courage to say: *this policy is backwards; invest in prevention, not punishment.*

critic_report.overall_analysis_mne:
Ova odluka je primjer dobro namijenjene, ali loše sprovedene politike — snažna u političkom signaliziranju, slaba u dokazima i planiranju implementacije.

**Pozitivno:** Vlada pravilno prepoznaje mlade vozače i električne trotinete kao prioritete bezbjednosti saobraćaja. Podaci EU podržavaju postepeno licenciranje, a crnogorska stopa smrtnosti od 7-8 na 100.000 zahtijeva djelovanje. Postavljanje digitalnih radara modernizuje sprovođenje zakona. Mehanizam roditeljske odgovornosti za prekršaje na trotinetima je pravno utemeljen i adresira realan nedostatak.

**Negativno:** Ovo je politički teatar maskiran u reformu. Zabrana vožnje poslije ponoći zvuči strogo, ali nema mehanizam sprovođenja — hoće li policija postavljati kontrolne punktove na svakom seoskom putu? Mladi vozači će jednostavno pozajmljivati roditeljska vozila ili registrovati vozila na imena članova porodice. Nabavka radara od 1,5-5 miliona eura nema izvor budžeta, ni vremenski okvir, ni garancije transparentnosti i — što je ključno — ni analizu troškova i koristi. Hoće li 100 radara spasiti više života nego ulaganje 5 miliona eura u helikoptere hitne pomoći za ruralni transport traumatizovanih? Ne znamo, jer Vlada nije ni pitala.

**Najgore:** Zabrinutost oko ustavne jednakosti je realna. Punoljetne osobe (18-21) mogu glasati, sklapati brak, posjedovati imovinu i služiti vojsku — ali ne smiju voziti na noćnu smjenu? Venecijanska komisija bi vjerovatno ovo označila kao neproporcionalno. Oduzimanje vozila bez neposrednog sudskog razmatranja krši pravo na imovinu prema EKLJP. Zakon stvara prilike za korupciju: diskreciona policijska ovlašćenja, veliki ugovor o nabavci, proširena ovlašćenja komunalne policije — sve bez pomenutog nadzora.

**Šta su ministarstva propustila:** Nijedno nije izračunalo trošak ljudskog kapitala: svaki spašeni mladi život vrijedi ~3-5 miliona eura u životnoj produktivnosti (standard EU). Nijedno nije dovelo u pitanje zašto Crna Gora kopira kaznene mjere EU (policijski čas, ograničenja snage), ali ignoriše dokazanu prevenciju: švedska Vizija nula ulaže u projektovanje puteva i liječenje trauma; Holandija se fokusira na infrastrukturno razdvajanje. Nijedno nije pitalo: ako ovo funkcioniše, zašto Francuska i Austrija — sa sličnim ograničenjima — i dalje imaju veću stopu smrtnosti mladih nego Švedska i UK, koje koriste pristupe zasnovane na edukaciji?

**Prava priča:** Ova odluka štiti Vladu od kritika ("uradili smo nešto povodom smrtnih slučajeva na putevima") bez rješavanja problema. Kriza bezbjednosti saobraćaja u Crnoj Gori potiče od: loše putne infrastrukture (uski, slabo osvjetljeni planinski putevi), slabog sprovođenja zabrane vožnje pod uticajem alkohola (alkotestovi se rijetko koriste), neadekvatne pokrivenosti hitne medicinske službe (>30 minuta vremena odziva u ruralnim područjima) i kulturnog prihvatanja bezobzirne vožnje. Zabrana vožnje poslije ponoći za osobe od 18-21 godine ne adresira ništa od toga.

**Cui bono?** Dobavljači radara (ugovor od 1,5-5 miliona eura bez garancija konkurentnog tendera). Policijski sindikati (proširena ovlašćenja, veći budžeti). Političari (retorika "strogi prema bezbjednosti saobraćaja"). Nemaju koristi: mladi radnici koji gube mogućnosti zarade, ruralne porodice sa ograničenim prevozom, poreski obveznici koji finansiraju nefinansirane mandate, ili — što je najvažnije — stvarne žrtve krize bezbjednosti saobraćaja u Crnoj Gori, koje će nastaviti da ginu jer ovaj zakon tretira simptome, a ne uzroke.

**EU ugao:** Brisel će aplaudirati optici ("harmonizacija!"), ali vlastite smjernice Evropske komisije za procjenu uticaja zahtijevaju analizu troškova i koristi, konsultacije sa zainteresovanim stranama, pregled proporcionalnosti i procjenu alternativa. Ova odluka nema ništa od toga. Da je Crna Gora ovo podnijela kao EU zakonodavstvo, palo bi na provjeri. Zašto prihvatati niže standarde na domaćem nivou?

**Zaključak:** Odluka ocjenjena 6/10 — bolje od ničega, gore od politike zasnovane na dokazima. Umjereno će smanjiti neke nesreće mladih (možda 5-10% u ograničenoj starosnoj grupi), dok stvara haos u sprovođenju, ustavne izazove i propuštene prilike za sistemsku reformu. Ministarstva zaslužuju 8/10 za kvalitet procjene — prepoznala su realne probleme — ali nijedno nije imalo hrabrosti da kaže: *ova politika je pogrešna; ulagajte u prevenciju, a ne u kažnjavanje.*

Oportunitetni trošak u odnosu na alternative zasnovane na dokazima: Zašto kazneni policijski čas umjesto ulaganja u edukaciju o postepenom licenciranju, subvencije za naprednu obuku vozača ili sprovođenje nulte tolerancije alkohola za sve vozače?

Rizik po turističku konkurentnost: Albanija i Hrvatska se promovišu kao destinacije prijateljske prema mladima; zabrana vožnje poslije ponoći može odvratiti mlade turiste iz EU i digitalne nomade koji očekuju slobodu kretanja

counter_proposal.title: Phased Road Safety System with Fiscal Discipline, Educational Integration, and Health Outcomes Focus
counter_proposal.executive_summary: Instead of immediate full enforcement, implement a three-year phased road safety program combining evidence-based restrictions with institutional capacity-building, sustainable financing, and public health integration. Deploy digital radars in pilot corridors with proven cost-effectiveness thresholds, establish a self-financing Road Safety Fund from fine revenues, mandate traffic safety education in schools and driver rehabilitation programs, require judicial oversight for vehicle seizures, integrate health sector injury data into enforcement planning, and create inter-ministerial coordination to address root causes beyond policing.
counter_proposal.detailed_proposal:
The AI Government's counter-proposal maintains the core protective measures—young driver restrictions, electric scooter regulation, and modern enforcement technology—while addressing critical gaps in fiscal sustainability, constitutional compliance, educational prevention, and public health outcomes.

**Phase 1: Evidence-Based Pilot (Months 0-12)**

Begin with a 25-unit digital radar deployment in statistically high-risk corridors identified through joint analysis by the Ministry of Interior and Institute of Public Health injury surveillance data. This reduces upfront capital expenditure from €1.5-5 million to €375,000-1.25 million while validating cost assumptions. Expansion to 100 units proceeds only if cost-per-accident-prevented meets a €50,000 threshold, ensuring fiscal discipline and evidence-based scaling.

Conduct comprehensive baseline assessments: police capacity audit for enforcement technology, crash data integration pilot, regulatory impact assessment including Constitutional Court preliminary review, data protection impact assessment for GDPR compliance, and youth employment impact study focusing on tourism/hospitality night-shift workers.

**Phase 2: Institutional and Legal Refinement (Months 6-18)**

Replace the blanket midnight-to-5am driving ban with evidence-based graduated licensing measures that survive constitutional proportionality scrutiny: zero blood alcohol content for drivers under 21, mandatory 20-hour advanced safety training within the first year of licensure, and a penalty point system with lower thresholds for novice drivers (6 points vs. 12 for experienced drivers). Introduce work-related exemptions for young drivers with verified night-shift employment in registered businesses, protecting labor market flexibility in tourism-dependent coastal regions.

Amend vehicle seizure provisions to require judicial authorization within 24 hours, clearly defined qualifying offenses, maximum 30-day seizure periods, and automatic compensation for wrongful seizures. This addresses rule of law concerns and prevents ECHR Article 1 Protocol 1 violations.

Expand electric scooter regulation to include mandatory helmet requirements (EN 1078 standard), speed limits (25 km/h), dedicated lane usage rules, and rental company licensing obligations. Introduce means-tested fine structures for parental liability: €50-150 for low-income families, €150-300 for median income, €300-500 for high income, with community service alternatives.

**Phase 3: Educational and Public Health Integration (Months 12-24)**

Mandatory 12-hour traffic safety module integrated into the final year of all secondary schools (gymnasium and vocational), covering defensive driving, legal responsibilities, injury biomechanics, and new young driver restrictions. Annual school-police partnership programs with traffic officers presenting regulations and accident case studies at all secondary schools each September.

Certify Vocational Education and Training (VET) centers to deliver 8-hour road safety courses for first-time young offenders as an alternative to monetary fines, creating a rehabilitation pathway and revenue stream for VET institutions. Update VET curriculum for auto mechanics and transport technicians with a 16-hour road safety module covering vehicle dynamics and young driver risks.

Establish 'Road Trauma Reality' workshops for first-time violators, featuring health-led education on injury consequences and survivor testimonials—proven more effective than fines alone in changing long-term behavior.

**Phase 4: Sustainable Financing and Transparency (Ongoing)**

Create a dedicated Road Safety Fund where all fine revenue is earmarked for safety infrastructure and services, ensuring self-financing and preventing revenue diversion. Allocate fund resources: 30% to school-zone safety infrastructure (crosswalks, speed bumps, signage near hospitals and schools), 30% to Emergency Medical Services modernization (trauma training, ambulance renewal, rural response time improvements), 20% to educational materials and public awareness campaigns, 10% to University of Montenegro road safety research with graduate student involvement, 10% to administration and monitoring.

Establish transparent revenue-sharing: 70% central government, 30% municipalities for parking fines, incentivizing local enforcement while preserving central budget revenues.

Publish quarterly public dashboards tracking fine revenue, enforcement costs, accident rates, injury severity trends, youth employment effects, and return-on-investment. This ensures accountability and enables data-driven policy adjustments.

**Phase 5: Inter-Ministerial Coordination and Health Outcomes (Months 18-36)**

Create a permanent National Road Safety Council co-chaired by the Ministers of Interior and Health, with mandatory participation from Transport, Education, Justice, Finance, and Economy. The Council meets quarterly using integrated data from police enforcement, health sector injury surveillance (Institute of Public Health, Clinical Center emergency departments), and economic indicators (tourism employment, informal sector activity).

Mandatory real-time data exchange: police provide crash and citation data to the Institute of Public Health within 48 hours, enabling epidemiological monitoring and evidence-based enforcement priority-setting. Use health sector injury mapping to guide radar placement, prioritizing high-injury corridors rather than revenue-generating highways.

Expand beyond young driver focus to address vulnerable road users: 30 km/h urban speed limits near schools and hospitals, protected cycling infrastructure investment, pedestrian priority zones informed by health injury data.

Introduce comprehensive alcohol strategy: zero-BAC for all drivers (not just young/novice), random breath testing authority, and emergency department screening protocols to identify high-risk individuals for brief intervention.

**Phase 6: EU Integration and Regional Leadership (Months 12-36)**

Explicitly cite EU Directive 2015/413 on cross-border enforcement and the Road Safety Action Programme 2021-2030 in the law's preamble, demonstrating acquis transposition for Chapter 14 (Transport Policy) and Chapter 23 (Judiciary and Fundamental Rights).

Establish a roadmap for EUCARIS (European Car and Driving License Information System) integration by 2027, with bilateral data-exchange agreements with Croatia, Serbia, Albania, and Bosnia-Herzegovina for cross-border enforcement.

Designate IPA III as the primary funding source for digital radars and capacity-building, ensuring compliance with EU public procurement rules and leveraging €2-4 million in potential technical and financial assistance.

Initiate a Regional Road Safety Working Group under the Transport Community Treaty, with Montenegro hosting a ministerial conference in Q3 2026 to position the country as a reform leader and create harmonized Western Balkans standards.

**Phase 7: Evaluation and Adaptation (Years 2-3)**

Include a 3-year sunset clause for all young driver restrictions, requiring mandatory independent evaluation of road safety outcomes, constitutional rights impact, health metrics (lives saved, serious injuries prevented, disability-adjusted life years), and economic effects before renewal.

Set measurable targets aligned with EU Vision Zero: 20% reduction in road traffic fatalities by 2028, 30% reduction in serious injuries, specific sub-targets for 18-21 age group based on baseline data.

If fine revenue fails to cover 80% of enforcement costs within 24 months, the program undergoes mandatory review and potential restructuring to ensure fiscal sustainability.

**Municipal Police and Anti-Corruption Safeguards**

Delay delegation of expanded municipal police authority until standardized training, equipment, and anti-corruption oversight are certified by the Ministry of Interior. Prioritize municipalities meeting defined capacity thresholds.

Require body cameras for all traffic enforcement interactions involving potential vehicle seizure or fines exceeding €200, with footage retained for 90 days and accessible to defendants. The Agency for Prevention of Corruption (ASK) publishes quarterly statistics on seizures by region and officer to detect patterns of abuse.

Subject all radar procurement to enhanced transparency: public tender with published evaluation criteria, State Audit Institution pre-approval, real-time contract publication on gov.me, and civil society observer participation.

**Implementation Feasibility**

This phased approach is highly feasible because it builds on the government's existing decision rather than replacing it, requires no additional legislative approvals beyond refinements, and leverages available EU IPA III funding. The Ministry of Interior already possesses crash location data; the Institute of Public Health operates injury surveillance systems; schools have existing civic education frameworks; and VET centers have accreditation infrastructure. The main challenge is inter-ministerial coordination, addressable through existing Government Coordination Body mechanisms with a clear Prime Minister's Office mandate. Total additional first-year cost: €200,000-500,000, largely offset by fine revenue and EU co-financing within 18-24 months.
